PrimEcoSys: Central and Southern Appalachian Spruce-Fir Forest

habitat_description: Endemic to the eastern highlands of West Virgina, Plethodon nettingi was formerly included with P. hubrichti and P. shenandoah as a single species until Highton and Larson (1979) elevated the previous two to species status based on moderate levels of genetic divergence. P. nettingi has been found at elevations ranging from 750 meters (Pauley 1991) to 1378 meters (Pauley 1980, 1981). They are largely restricted to red spruce-yellow birch forest but have been found to inhabit mixed deciduous hardwoods, and scattered hemlock/spruce (Clovis 1979, Green and Pauley 1987, Pauley et al. 2005). They are associated with boulder fields, rock outcrops, and steep ravines within dense Rhododenron groves (Pauley 1998).
